lines.text: the James boys, the Daltons and the Youngers... The year, 1866. The place is Southern Indiana.
So it finally happened. A Reno brother got killed.
Clint, we don't want no preaching.
Take it easy, Sim.
The baby of the family dying in the streets and his brave brothers running away. Not even animals would do a thing like that!
Dead in the streets... not dying.
As if that made a difference!
Thirty thousand dollars is a heap of money. Now, who would have thought of holding up a train?
Seems like a business worth considering.
They're shrewd, those Renos, and vicious. Control the whole county in southern Indiana. Judge, prosecutor, constable - all on their side! Renos had 'em elected.
I still wonder how a thing like that could happen.
Well, people who have had freedom for as long as we've had sometimes take it for granted. Come election day, they're lazy, or callous. Same thing. However, it's done. Our job is to get it undone.

[Discussing former Confederate spy James Barlow]
I'm still wondering how he got hold of so many secrets.
Certain generals' wives found him very charming.
Irresistible is the word, Dad. as a matter of fact, I recall...
Oh, I wasn't the only one who invited him to dinner. Secretary Stanton had him, too. Immodest as it may sound, man could fool Stanton and me could fool the Reno boys.

[to the sheriff and prosecutor]
You're too suspicious.
We've a right to be suspicious. Our share keeps getting smaller and smaller; first thing you know they'll deal us out completely.
How can they? We'll be re-elected next month for two more years. They know which side their bread's buttered on.

You think we can get away with this for two more years? Our collusion with the Reno Brothers is one of the worst kept secrets in history. Collusion, conspiracy, malfeasance. Ugly words, your honor, but true. We've got to be realistic.

[Riding up moments after watching Barlow flirting with Laura Reno]
You aimin' on gettin' yourself killed?
On the contrary. I was just planning my future.
I don't like you, Barlow. Don't like you a'tall. But I admire guts.

[Looking at the corrupt politians walking down the street]
There kind'd never be elected if the women folk could vote.
Yeah, but we'll get the vote one day.

[Angrily, to his three surviving brothers]
You're notorious outlaws. The law will get you sooner or later, and they'll get you any way they can - in the back, ambush, while you're sleepin' - they'll get yuh. Bill's death was only the beginning.

[Upset t hear one of her brothers was klled in a bungled bank robbery]
This time it was Bill and the next time somebody else.
That's the way it is, Laura.
It doesn't have to be.
You could leave the state. You could go somewhere where nobody ever heard of the Renos.
Where would that be?
When you ride with us, Barlow, don't ask no questions.

[after he's ordered the gang to split up after the robbery and sees Barlow following him]
I reckon you didn't hear me right. I said this is where we split up.
I don't know this country.

[Gesturing in the direction of the other gang members]
Well, go with one of them.
I'm goin' with you seeing as how you're the one that's got the money

[as Barlow comes in with something on his mind]
Where have you been, Jim? What happened?
Several interesting things, Monk.

[preoccupied with the letter he's writing]
Several... interesting... things...
I'm sorry if I disappoint you, Miss Laura, but as you know in our business, a little dishonesty's necessary now and then.
